habitat_description:
Olympic torrent salamanders occur only in the region of the Olympic Peninsula, south to the Chehalis River in Washington (Good and Wake 1992; McAllister 1995; Green et al. 2013; Stebbins 2003). It is important to note the absence of this species in the Black Hills complex near the southern margin of Puget Sound still north of the Chehalis River (McAllister 1995). More recent research has reported this species to be widespread across streams and seeps of the region (Bury and Adams 2000). 

Habitat of preference appears to include cold, clear streams, waterfalls, and seepages (Leonard et al. 1993; Nussbaum and Tait 1977). Stebbins and Lowe (1951), have described general vegetation requirements of torrent salamanders that effectively provide leaf canopy during the summer to include abundant understory vegetation, thick leaf mats, and thick layers of moss.

Microhabitats with loose gravel, cobble, and open interstices with limited sediments that are fine are preferred (Welsh and Lind 1996).
